desc: LATS2 encodes a tumor suppressor involved in regulation of the Hippo signaling pathway. Loss of heterozygosity mutations of LATS2 are found in breast, ovarian and liver cancers, among others.

Lats2 (large tumor suppressor 2), a serine/threonine kinase acts as a tumor suppressor which is implicated in the regulation of cell cycle. The human LATS2 gene was mapped onto chromosome 13q11-12 (PMID:10673337). A frequent LOH of this locus has also been reported in various cancers including breast, ovary, and liver (PMID:3388033, 1655245, 2904349). Overexpression of LATS2 causes G1-S arrest through the inhibition of cyclin E/CDK2 in vitro as well as suppresses the tumorigenicity of NIH/v-ras-transformed cells in vivo. Malignant mesothelioma was demonstrated to have suppressed LATS2 levels (PMID:21245096).In the central axis of Hippo pathway, LATS2 is phosphorylated by MST1/2 at Ser-872 and Thr-1041, and the phosphorylation is enhanced by the presence of MOB1, a regulator of Hippo pathway. Ser-380 of LATS2 can be phosphorylated by Aurora A, a regulator of cell division (PMID: 15688006, 16674920, 18328708). KIBRA is another regulator that stabilizes the LATS2 by inhibiting its ubiquitination, and KIBRA overexpression could also promote YAP phosphorylation through LATS2 (PMID:21233212). At the mRNA level, LATS2 transcripts are regulated by several microRNAs. MiR-372 and miR-373 were reported to exert their oncogenic potentials by targeting LATS2 in testicular germ cell tumors (PMID: 16564011). miR-31 is another microRNA that targets LATS2, as shown in lung cancer (PMID: 20237410).
